quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: Elevators, Friction, and Basic Force Applications (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Applied Force Problems and Real-World Scenarios

questions.question: A person stands on a scale in an elevator. When will the scale read less than their actual weight?
options: When the elevator moves at constant speed
questions.explanation: Downward acceleration reduces the normal force, making the scale read less.

questions.question: Which of the following is a contact force?
questions.explanation: Friction requires physical contact between surfaces, making it a contact force.

questions.question: A 5 kg box is pushed with 30 N on a surface with μₖ = 0.4. What is its acceleration?
Which free-body diagram shows a car moving right at constant speed?
options: Large arrow right, small arrow left
questions.explanation: Constant speed means zero net force - engine force right equals friction/air resistance left.

questions.question: A 60 kg person on a scale in an accelerating elevator reads 720 N. What is the elevator's acceleration?
What is the net force on a 2 kg object accelerating at 3 m/s² while experiencing 8 N of friction?
questions.explanation: F_net = ma = 2 × 3 = 6 N. But this is net after friction. Applied force = net + friction = 6 + 8 = 14 N.

questions.question: A rocket of mass 1000 kg expels gas at 500 m/s with 200 kg/s. What is thrust?
questions.explanation: Thrust = (dm/dt) × v = 200 kg/s × 500 m/s = 100,000 N.

questions.question: Why do action-reaction forces not cancel?
options: They are in the same direction
questions.explanation: Action-reaction pairs act on different objects, so they don't cancel for either object.

questions.question: A 10 kg block on a 30° incline has μₛ = 0.6. Will it slide?
questions.explanation: mg sin30° = 10×9.8×0.5 = 49 N down incline. Max static friction = μₛmg cos30° = 0.6×98×0.866 = 51 N. Friction > component, so no slide.

questions.question: What is the reaction force to a ball hitting a wall?
questions.explanation: The wall pushes back on the ball with equal force (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: A car rounds a curve at constant speed. Why is it accelerating?
questions.explanation: Changing direction requires centripetal acceleration, even at constant speed.

questions.question: Two boxes (5 kg and 10 kg) are pushed with 45 N. What force does the 5 kg box exert on the 10 kg box?
questions.explanation: Total mass = 15 kg, a = 45/15 = 3 m/s². Force on 10 kg box = 10 × 3 = 30 N.

questions.question: Why does oil reduce friction?
questions.explanation: Lubricants create a smooth fluid layer that separates surfaces, reducing direct contact.

questions.question: A 500 N crate requires 250 N to start moving. What is μₛ?
questions.explanation: μₛ = fₛ_max/N = 250 N / 500 N = 0.5

questions.question: What is terminal velocity?
options: Speed when air resistance equals weight
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity occurs when upward air resistance equals downward weight.

questions.question: A 2 kg object has weight 19.6 N on Earth. On the Moon, what is its mass?
questions.explanation: Mass is amount of matter and doesn't change with location.

questions.question: Why do rockets work in space?
options: Newton's Third Law works in vacuum
questions.explanation: Expelling mass creates reaction force regardless of atmosphere (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: A 1000 kg car accelerates from 0 to 27 m/s in 9 seconds. What average power is needed?
What force allows walking?
questions.explanation: Foot pushes ground backward, ground pushes foot forward (action-reaction).

questions.question: A 50 kg box is pulled with 200 N at 37° above horizontal (μₖ = 0.3). What is acceleration?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of applied force problems and real-world scenarios.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand most concepts but should review elevator problems and friction calculations.
scoreMessages.50: A fair effort. Focus on practicing multi-force systems and Newton's Third Law applications.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review the fundamental force concepts and work through basic applied problems.
